text: David Keith Lynch (born January 20, 1946) is an American filmmaker, painter, musician, actor, and photographer.
title: David Lynch

text: He is best known for films such as "Eraserhead" (1977), "Blue Velvet" (1986) and "Mulholland Drive" (2001), often regarded by critics as among the best films of their respective decades, and for his successful 1990–91 television series "Twin Peaks", which led to him being labeled "the first popular Surrealist" by noted film critic Pauline Kael.
title: David Lynch

text: A recipient of an Academy Honorary Award in 2019, he has received three Academy Award nominations for Best Director, and has won France's César Award for Best Foreign Film twice, as well as the Palme d'Or at the Cannes Film Festival and a Golden Lion award for lifetime achievement at the Venice Film Festival.
title: David Lynch

text: He has been described by "The Guardian" as "the most important director of this era", while AllMovie called him "the Renaissance man of modern American filmmaking".
title: David Lynch

text: Born to a middle-class family in Missoula, Montana, Lynch spent his childhood traveling around the United States before he studied painting at the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts in Philadelphia, where he first made the transition to producing short films.
title: David Lynch

text: He moved to Los Angeles, where he produced his first motion picture, the surrealist horror film "Eraserhead" (1977).
title: David Lynch

text: After "Eraserhead" became a success on the midnight movie circuit, Lynch was employed to direct the biographical film "The Elephant Man" (1980), from which he gained mainstream success.
title: David Lynch

text: He was then employed by the De Laurentiis Entertainment Group and proceeded to make two films: the science-fiction epic "Dune" (1984), which proved to be a critical and commercial failure, and then a neo-noir mystery film "Blue Velvet" (1986), which stirred controversy over its violence but later grew in critical reputation.
title: David Lynch

text: Next, Lynch created his own television series with Mark Frost, the popular murder mystery entitled "Twin Peaks" (1990–1991).
title: David Lynch

text: He also created a cinematic prequel,  (1992), a road film "Wild at Heart" (1990) and a family film "The Straight Story" (1999) in the same period.
title: David Lynch

text: Turning further towards surrealist filmmaking, three of his subsequent films operated on dream logic non-linear narrative structures: "Lost Highway" (1997), "Mulholland Drive" (2001), and "Inland Empire" (2006).
title: David Lynch

text: Meanwhile, Lynch embraced the Internet as a medium, producing several web-based shows, such as the animated "DumbLand" (2002) and the surreal sitcom "Rabbits" (2002).
title: David Lynch

text: Lynch and Frost reunited for a third season of "Twin Peaks", airing in on Showtime in 2017.
title: David Lynch

text: Lynch co-wrote and directed every episode, as well as reprising his role as Gordon Cole.
title: David Lynch

text: Lynch's other artistic endeavours include: his work as a musician, encompassing three studio albums—"BlueBOB" (2001), "Crazy Clown Time" (2011) and "The Big Dream" (
title: David Lynch

text: 2013)—as well as music and sound design for a variety of his films; painting and photography; writing three books—"Images" (1994), "Catching the Big Fish" (2006), and "Room to Dream" (2018); and directing several music videos and advertisements, including the Dior promotional film "Lady Blue Shanghai" (2006).
title: David Lynch

text: An avid practitioner of Transcendental Meditation (TM), Lynch founded the David Lynch Foundation in 2005, which sought to fund the teaching of TM in schools and has since widened its scope to other at-risk populations, including the homeless, veterans and refugees.
title: David Lynch

text: In 2019, he received an Academy Honorary Award; his first Oscar win.
title: David Lynch

text: Ronnie Rocket is an unfinished film project written by David Lynch, who also intended to direct it.
title: Ronnie Rocket

text: Begun after the success of Lynch's 1977 film "EraserheadRonnie Rocket" was shelved after Lynch felt he would be unable to find financial backing for the project.
title: Ronnie Rocket

text: He instead sought out an existing script on which to base his next film, settling on what would become 1980's "The Elephant Man".
title: Ronnie Rocket

text: "Ronnie Rocket" was to feature many of the elements which have since come to be seen as Lynch's hallmarks; including industrial art direction, 1950s popular culture and physical deformity.
title: Ronnie Rocket

text: The script featured a three-foot tall man with control over electricity; Lynch first met Michael J. Anderson when tentatively casting for this role, and later cast him in "Twin Peaks" and "Mulholland Drive" as a result.
title: Ronnie Rocket

text: Charles Armand René de La Trémoille (14 January 1708, in Paris – 23 May 1741),
title: Charles Armand René de La Trémoille

text: 6th duc de Thouars, was the son of Charles Louis Bretagne de La Trémoille and his wife, Marie Madeleine Motier de la Fayette.
title: Charles Armand René de La Trémoille

text: La Trémoille was a French soldier and president of the States of Brittany.
title: Charles Armand René de La Trémoille

text: He joined the military at a young age and became a colonel of the Champagne regiment at the age of eighteen.
title: Charles Armand René de La Trémoille

text: Later, he became governor of Île-de-France.
title: Charles Armand René de La Trémoille

text: He distinguished himself in the battle of Guastalla, in Italy, and was named shortly thereafter sergeant of the armies of the king.
title: Charles Armand René de La Trémoille

text: La Trémoille was the author of some works and was elected a member of the Académie française on 13 February 1738.
title: Charles Armand René de La Trémoille

text: On 29 January 1725 he married his cousin Marie Hortense de La Tour d'Auvergne, the daughter of Marie Armande Victoire de la Trémoïlle (1677–1717) and Emmanuel-Théodose de La Tour d'Auvergne, duc de Bouillon (1668–1730).
title: Charles Armand René de La Trémoille

text: Marie Hortense, like her husband was a granddaughter of Charles Belgique Hollande de La Trémoille.
title: Charles Armand René de La Trémoille

text: From this union was born a son:
title: Charles Armand René de La Trémoille

text: Jean Bretagne Charles de La Trémoille and a daughter who died in infancy.
title: Charles Armand René de La Trémoille

text: Prince Charles Bretagne Marie de La Trémoille (24 March 1764 – 10 November 1839), 8th Duke of Thouars, 7th Duke of La Trémoïlle, 10th prince de Tarente, 14th prince de Talmond and 14th Count of Laval, was a French aristocrat and soldier; he was the son of Jean Bretagne Charles de La Trémoille and his wife Princess Marie-Maximilienne of Salm-Kyrburg.
title: Charles Bretagne Marie de La Trémoille

text: Henri Charles de La Trémoille( 17 December 1620 – 14 September 1672) was a French military commander.
title: Henri Charles de La Trémoille

text: He the son of Henry de La Trémoille, duc of Thouars and of La Trémoille, and his wife, Marie de La Tour d'Auvergne.
title: Henri Charles de La Trémoille

text: In 1628, La Trémoille's father, Henri III of Trémoïlle, converted himself and his children to Catholicism, but La Trémoille's mother convinced him to reconvert to Protestantism when he reached the age of majority.
title: Henri Charles de La Trémoille

text: In 1638, he joined the army of his uncle, Frederick Henry, Prince of Orange.
title: Henri Charles de La Trémoille

text: In 1648, he married the Calvinist Émilie of Hesse- Kassel, the daughter of William V of Hesse- Kassel( or Hesse- Cassel).
title: Henri Charles de La Trémoille

text: They had five children, including Charles Belgique, his heir, and Charlotte Amélie de la Trémoille.
title: Henri Charles de La Trémoille

text: In October 1651, during the Fronde, he came out against Cardinal Mazarin and supported Condé openly.
title: Henri Charles de La Trémoille

text: As a result, in 1656 he was imprisoned in Amiens.
title: Henri Charles de La Trémoille

text: La Trémoille's mother obtained his release after several months of imprisonment.
title: Henri Charles de La Trémoille

text: He was then relegated in Poitou then turned over to serve in Holland.
title: Henri Charles de La Trémoille

text: In 1668, he returned from Holland to manage the affairs of the duchy of Thouars, his father being weakened by the gout, and he again re-converted to Catholicism, taking away the children from his wife who fled to the Netherlands.
title: Henri Charles de La Trémoille

text: He died two years before his father in 1672; it was thus his elder son, Charles, who succeeded as the fourth duke of Thouars.
title: Henri Charles de La Trémoille

text: Claude de La Trémoille, 2nd Duke of Thouars (1566 – 25 October 1604) was a sixteenth-century French nobleman of the La Tremoille family.
title: Claude de La Trémoille

text: He was the son of Louis III de La Trémoille and his wife, Jeanne de Montmorency.
title: Claude de La Trémoille

text: King Henry IV of France had been friendly with La Trémoille when he was King of Navarre, but kept him in a subordinate position once he became King of France, preferring La Trémoille's cousin, Henry de La Tour d'Auvergne, the Viscount of Turenne.
title: Claude de La Trémoille

text: In 1587, La Trémoille converted to Protestantism.
title: Claude de La Trémoille

text: He fought for Henry IV at the battle of Coutras and also at Ivry, and was rewarded by elevation to the peerage, as Duke of Thouars, in 1595.
title: Claude de La Trémoille

text: This new title, however, made La Trémoille lose more money than it earned him.
title: Claude de La Trémoille

text: In 1598, Turenne proposed to his sister-in-law Charlotte-Brabantine to marry La Trémoille.
title: Claude de La Trémoille

text: Thanks to her relations with the houses of Orange and Bouillon, Charlotte-Brabantine played an important part in the French Protestant diplomacy.
title: Claude de La Trémoille

text: They had four children: Henry; Charlotte, who married James Stanley, Earl of Derby; Élisabeth (1601–1604); and Frédéric (1602–1642) comte de Laval.
title: Claude de La Trémoille

text: In 1602, Charlotte-Brabantine dissuaded her husband from engaging in the conspiracy of Biron and encouraged him to lend allegiance to the king.
title: Claude de La Trémoille

text: He died in 1604.
title: Claude de La Trémoille

text: " Not to be confused with Charlotte Stanley, Countess of Derby."
title: Charlotte de La Trémoille

text: Eystein Glumra(" Eystein the Noisy" or" Eystein the Clatterer"; Modern Norwegian" Øystein Glumra") also known as Eystein Ivarsson, was reputedly a petty king on the west coast of Norway, during the 9th Century.
title: Eystein Glumra

text: The" Heimskringla" saga states that Eystein Glumra was the father of Rognvald Eysteinsson and Sigurd Eysteinsson:" The first earl in the Orkney Islands was called Sigurd, who was a son of Eystein Glumra, and brother of Ragnvald earl of More.
title: Eystein Glumra

text: After Sigurd, his son Guthorm was earl for one year.
title: Eystein Glumra

text: After him Torf- Einar, a son of Ragnvald, took the earldom, and was long earl, and was a man of great power".
title: Eystein Glumra

text: According to the" Orkneyinga Saga", Eystein Glumra was the son of Ivar the jarl of Uplanders and grandson of Halfdan the Old.

title: Eystein Glumra

text: Ioan S. Nenițescu (April 11, 1854–February 23, 1901) was a Romanian poet and playwright.
title: Ioan S. Nenițescu

text: Born in Galați, his parents were Ștefan Vasiliu, a manual laborer, and his wife Elisabeta ("née" Zaharia).
title: Ioan S. Nenițescu

text: After completing the Alexandru Ioan
title: Ioan S. Nenițescu

text: I commercial school in his native town
title: Ioan S. Nenițescu

text: , he finished high school, passing the exit examination at Iași.
title: Ioan S. Nenițescu

text: He also audited courses at Iași University's literature faculty.
title: Ioan S. Nenițescu

text: Nenițescu attended an officers' school, volunteered in the Romanian War of Independence and was wounded at Grivitsa.
title: Ioan S. Nenițescu

text: He then studied at the philosophy faculty of Berlin University, taking a doctorate in 1887 at Leipzig University with a thesis on Baruch Spinoza.
title: Ioan S. Nenițescu

text: He worked as a schoolteacher and inspector in Bucharest.
title: Ioan S. Nenițescu

text: He traveled south of the Danube, a trip that resulted in an ample "ethnic and statistical study of the AromaniansDe la românii din Turcia Europeană", 1895).
title: Ioan S. Nenițescu

text: He sat in the Assembly of Deputies for his native Covurlui County, and also served as prefect of Tulcea County in the Dobruja region.
title: Ioan S. Nenițescu

text: Nenițescu's first work appeared in the Galați newspaper "Gardistul civic".
title: Ioan S. Nenițescu

text: A member of "Junimea", he published numerous poems in its organ "Convorbiri Literare".
title: Ioan S. Nenițescu

text: He also contributed to "AlbinaAmicul copiilorRevista nouăRomânul literarȘezătoarea" and "Ziarul presei".
title: Ioan S. Nenițescu

text: While in Bucharest from 1884 to 1888, he published "Țara nouă" magazine, mainly submitting articles on pedagogy, ethics and sociology.
title: Ioan S. Nenițescu

text: His first book was the 1880 poetry volume "Flori de primăvară", followed by "Șoimii de la Războieni" (1882) and "Pui de lei" (1891).
title: Ioan S. Nenițescu

text: Of the plays he wrote, the only one he published was "Radu de la Afumați" (1897).
title: Ioan S. Nenițescu

text: In 1896, Nenițescu was elected a corresponding member of the Romanian Academy.
title: Ioan S. Nenițescu

text: He died in Buzău.
title: Ioan S. Nenițescu

text: His son Ștefan also became a poet.
title: Ioan S. Nenițescu

text: Ștefan I. Nenițescu (October 8, 1897–October 1979) was a Romanian poet and aesthetician.
title: Ștefan I. Nenițescu

text: Born in Bucharest, his parents were the poet Ioan S. Nenițescu and his wife Elena ("née" Ștefan).
title: Ștefan I. Nenițescu

text: He attended Sapienza University of Rome from 1920, as well as the literature and philosophy department of Bucharest University.
title: Ștefan I. Nenițescu

text: At first an assistant professor of aesthetics, he later became an associate professor at Bucharest.
title: Ștefan I. Nenițescu

text: He served as press secretary and later economic adviser to the Romanian legation in The Hague.
title: Ștefan I. Nenițescu

text: Nenițescu's first publication was a 1915 article about William Shakespeare that appeared in "Noua revistă română".
title: Ștefan I. Nenițescu

text: His first book of poetry, "Denii" (1919), was followed by "Vrajă" (1923) and "Ode italice" (1925).
title: Ștefan I. Nenițescu

text: His single volume of theatre was "Trei mistere" (1922).
title: Ștefan I. Nenițescu

text: From 1924, he wrote for "Gândirea", and was a founding member of Romania's PEN Club.
title: Ștefan I. Nenițescu

text: He also contributed poetry and art criticism to "Convorbiri LiterareIdeea europeanăVremeaUniversul literarViața RomâneascăAdevărul" and "Arta plastică".
title: Ștefan I. Nenițescu

text: In 1925, Nenițescu published a treatise, "Istoria artei ca filosofie a istoriei".
title: Ștefan I. Nenițescu

text: He translated from Benedetto Croce ("Aesthetic", 1922) and Niccolò Machiavelli ("The Mandrake", 1926).
title: Ștefan I. Nenițescu

text: Initially, Nenițescu's poetry was discursive and religious, in line with the "Gândirist" current.
title: Ștefan I. Nenițescu

text: His verse became progressively more hermetic, as can be seen in the anthology volume
title: Ștefan I. Nenițescu

text: Including texts published in the 1940s and '50s, it reveals the intellectualized lyric verse of an eminently classical nature.
title: Ștefan I. Nenițescu

text: The Ottawa High School and Junior High School, located at 526 and 506 S. Main St. respectively, are the historic former high school and junior high school in Ottawa, Kansas.
title: Ottawa High School and Junior High School

text: The high school was built in 1917, while the junior high school was built from 1927 to 1928; an enclosed hallway connecting the two buildings was built with the junior high school.
title: Ottawa High School and Junior High School

text: The high school was the first school in Ottawa to be built solely as a high school and the eighth school built in Ottawa.
title: Ottawa High School and Junior High School

text: George P. Washburn& Son designed the high school in the Collegiate Gothic style.
title: Ottawa High School and Junior High School

text: When the junior high school was constructed ten years later, the firm, by then known as Washburn& Stookey, designed the building in the same style as the high school.
title: Ottawa High School and Junior High School

text: In 1966, a new high school was built for the upper three classes of students; the freshman class moved to the building in 1976, and the old high school and junior high school became a middle school.
title: Ottawa High School and Junior High School

text: The two buildings were connected by a multi-purpose room in the same year.
title: Ottawa High School and Junior High School

text: The middle school later vacated the building.
title: Ottawa High School and Junior High School

text: The school was added to the National Register of Historic Places on October 6, 2000.
title: Ottawa High School and Junior High School

text: Fernando Fernández Gómez (28 August 1921 – 21 November 2007) better known as Fernando Fernán-Gómez was a Spanish actor, screenwriter, film director, theater director and member of the Royal Spanish Academy for seven years.
title: Fernando Fernán Gómez

text: He was born in Argentina while his mother, Spanish actress Carola Fernán-Gómez, was making a tour in Latin America.
title: Fernando Fernán Gómez

text: He would later use her surname for his stage name when he moved to Spain in 1924.
title: Fernando Fernán Gómez

text: After the Spanish Civil War he began to study law but interrupted his studies to work in theater.
title: Fernando Fernán Gómez

text: In 1942 he began to act in movies but also continued working on plays.
title: Fernando Fernán Gómez

text: He formed his own theater company and received awards for directing and writing.
title: Fernando Fernán Gómez

text: In the 1950s he began to direct movies, including the film of his novel, "El viaje a ninguna parte".
title: Fernando Fernán Gómez

text: He received praise for his 1958 comedy "La vida por delante", which led to a sequel, "La vida alrededor".
title: Fernando Fernán Gómez

text: In 1977, he won the Silver Bear for Best Actor at the 27th Berlin International Film Festival for his role in "The Anchorite".
title: Fernando Fernán Gómez

text: He won the award again at the 35th Berlin International Film Festival in 1985 for his role in "Stico" and finally the Honorary Golden Bear at the 55th Berlin International Film Festival in 2005.
title: Fernando Fernán Gómez

text: Having been very much in demand during the 1970s and 1980s, the 1990s was a less active period for him, but towards the end of his life, he enjoyed something of a revival, featuring in three major projects: "Todo sobre mi madrePlenilunio", and a starring role in the hit "La lengua de las mariposas".
title: Fernando Fernán Gómez

text: He married María Dolores Pradera in 1945; they divorced in 1959.
title: Fernando Fernán Gómez

text: He married Emma Cohen in 2000.
title: Fernando Fernán Gómez

text: Fernando Fernán Gómez died in Madrid on 21 November 2007 from a heart failure.
title: Fernando Fernán Gómez

text: As he was a lifelong anarchist, his coffin was covered in a black and red anarchist flag.
title: Fernando Fernán Gómez

text: Antiochus X Eusebes Philopator (–92 or 88 BC) was a Hellenistic Seleucid monarch who reigned as the King of Syria between 95 BC and 92 BC or 89/88 BC (224 SE (Seleucid year)).
title: Antiochus X Eusebes

text: He was the son of Antiochus IX and perhaps his Egyptian wife Cleopatra IV.
title: Antiochus X Eusebes

text: He lived in a period during which there was a general disintegration of Seleucid Syria characterized by civil wars, foreign interference by Ptolemaic Egypt and incursions by the Parthians.
title: Antiochus X Eusebes

text: Antiochus IX was killed in 95BC at the hands of Seleucus VI, the son of his half-brother and rival Antiochus VIII.
title: Antiochus X Eusebes

text: Antiochus X then went to the city of Aradus where he declared himself king.
title: Antiochus X Eusebes

text: He avenged his father by defeating Seleucus VI, who was eventually killed.
title: Antiochus X Eusebes

text: Antiochus X did not enjoy a stable reign as he had to face three of Seleucus VI's brothers,
title: Antiochus X Eusebes

text: Antiochus XI, Philip I and Demetrius III.
title: Antiochus X Eusebes

text: Antiochus XI defeated AntiochusX and expelled him from the capital Antioch in 93 BC.
title: Antiochus X Eusebes

text: A few months later, AntiochusX regained his position and killed Antiochus XI.
title: Antiochus X Eusebes

text: This led to both Philip I and Demetrius III becoming involved.
title: Antiochus X Eusebes

text: The civil war continued but its final outcome is uncertain due to the contradictions between different ancient historians' accounts.
title: Antiochus X Eusebes

text: AntiochusX married his stepmother, Antiochus IX's widow Cleopatra Selene, and had several children with her, including a future king Antiochus XIII.
title: Antiochus X Eusebes

text: The death of Antiochus X is shrouded in mystery.
title: Antiochus X Eusebes

text: The year of his demise is traditionally given by modern scholars as 92 BC, but other dates are also possible including the year 224 SE (89/88BC).
title: Antiochus X Eusebes

text: The most reliable account of his end is that of the first century historian Josephus, who wrote that AntiochusX marched east to fight off the Parthians who were attacking a queen called Laodice; the identity of this queen and who her people were continues to be debated.
title: Antiochus X Eusebes

text: Other accounts exist:
title: Antiochus X Eusebes

text: the ancient Greek historian Appian has AntiochusX defeated by the Armenian king Tigranes II and losing his kingdom; the third century historian Eusebius wrote that AntiochusX was defeated by his cousins and escaped to the Parthians before asking the Romans for help in having him reinstated on the throne.
title: Antiochus X Eusebes

text: Modern scholars prefer the account of Josephus and question practically every aspect of the versions presented by other ancient historians.
title: Antiochus X Eusebes

text: Numismatic evidence shows that AntiochusX was succeeded in Antioch by Demetrius III, who controlled the capital in SE (88/87 BC).
title: Antiochus X Eusebes

text: The Working Class Goes to Heaven( released in the US as Lulu the Tool) is a 1971 political drama film directed by Elio Petri.
title: The Working Class Goes to Heaven

text: It depicts a factory worker's realisation of his own condition as a simple" tool" in the process of production and, implicitly, his struggle with the trade unions.
title: The Working Class Goes to Heaven

text: The film competed at the 1972 Cannes Film Festival, where it tied with" The Mattei Affair" for the Grand Prix International du Festival, the festival's highest honour.
title: The Working Class Goes to Heaven

text: In Italy, it also won the David di Donatello for Best Film.

title: Escala en la ciudad

text: The Mattei Affair is a 1972 film directed by Francesco Rosi.
title: The Mattei Affair

text: It depicts the life and mysterious death of Enrico Mattei, an Italian businessman who in the aftermath of World War II managed to avoid the sale of the nascent Italian oil and hydrocarbon industry to US companies and developed them in the Eni, a state- owned oil company which rivaled the' seven sisters' for oil and gas deals in northern African and Middle Eastern countries.
title: The Mattei Affair

text: The film shared the" Grand Prix" with" The Working Class Goes to Heaven" at the 1972 Cannes Film Festival.
title: The Mattei Affair

text: Italian star Gian Maria Volonté was the leading actor in both films.
title: The Mattei Affair

text: The film is an innovative hybrid of documentary and fiction, representing Francesco Rosi ’s concept of cine- inchieste( film investigation).
title: The Mattei Affair

text: The flashback structure shows the influence of" Citizen Kane" and Rosi ’s" Salvatore Giuliano"( 1962).
title: The Mattei Affair

text: Rosi remains faithful to his neo-realist roots with on- location shooting and non-professional actors.
title: The Mattei Affair

text: The film is interspersed with footage of the director trying to find his friend, the investigative journalist Mauro De Mauro, who disappeared while doing research for the film.
title: The Mattei Affair

text: He was killed by the Sicilian Mafia, but like the death of Mattei, De Mauro ’s case was never solved.
title: The Mattei Affair

text: The Trial of Joan of Arc is a 1962 French historical film directed by Robert Bresson.
title: The Trial of Joan of Arc

text: Joan of Arc is played by Florence Delay.
title: The Trial of Joan of Arc

text: As with Bresson's most renowned films," The Trial of Joan of Arc" stars non-professional performers and is filmed in an extremely spare, restrained style.
title: The Trial of Joan of Arc

text: Bresson's screenplay is drawn from the transcriptions of Joan's trial and rehabilitation.
title: The Trial of Joan of Arc

text: Bresson's" Joan of Arc" is often compared with" The Passion of Joan of Arc"( 1928) by Carl Theodor Dreyer.
title: The Trial of Joan of Arc

text: Bresson compared that film unfavorably with his own, expressing his dislike of the actors'" grotesque buffooneries" in Dreyer's film.
title: The Trial of Joan of Arc

text: Daniel Hobbins is a Professor of History at the University of Notre Dame and an American historian specializing in Medieval France.
title: Daniel Hobbins

text: He has also written in the American Historical Review.
title: Daniel Hobbins

text: In this article, Hobbins writes on Jean Gerson.
title: Daniel Hobbins

text: Although his recent research involves Gerson, Dr. Hobbins' most significant work is" The Trial of Joan of Arc".
title: Daniel Hobbins

text: Published scholarly reviews have been universally positive.
title: Daniel Hobbins

text: For example, Wendy Maier of Oakton Community College writes that this" text is suitable for students, scholars, and anyone with an interest in Joan of Arc."
title: Daniel Hobbins

text: Other reviews note the significance of the book as being the" first translation of the trial transcripts in fifty years!"
title: Daniel Hobbins

text: Larissa Juliet Taylor, a professor at Colby College, says
title: Daniel Hobbins

text: " The entire scholarly community will welcome two new books that offer English translations of many Johannine sources -- Hobbins' trial translation and introduction, reviewed here, ..."
title: Daniel Hobbins

text: The reviewer thinks that Hobbins' book will be a useful for the classroom, because other editions of the trial transcripts are inadequate in various ways — not enough notes, bad OCR, etc.
title: Daniel Hobbins

text: If this reviewer is correct, Hobbins' book will probably be in use in many college courses.
title: Daniel Hobbins

text: Taylor's review ends:" Daniel Hobbins has provided an extraordinary service to the scholarly and educational community with this outstanding new translation of the Latin trial compilation.
title: Daniel Hobbins

text: Equally important, his critical introduction and notes stand alongside the most valuable recent contributions to scholarship on Joan of Arc."
title: Daniel Hobbins

text: Another positive reviewer refers to the book as" excellent" and" informative."
title: Daniel Hobbins

text: The reviewer asks why" do we need Hobbins' new English translation?"
title: Daniel Hobbins

text: The reasons given in this review by Susan Tiefenbrun are that Hobbins' book is" more reliable" and" more convenient."
title: Daniel Hobbins

text: He" gave guest lectures on Joan of Arc at Bowling Green State University( October 17) and at Ohio Northern University( October 23".
title: Daniel Hobbins

text: He is the recipient of the Nina Maria Gorrissen Prize and Fellow at the American Academy in Berlin for Fall 2011.
title: Daniel Hobbins

text: Robert Bresson( 25 September 1901 – 18 December 1999) was a French film director.
title: Robert Bresson

text: Known for his ascetic approach, Bresson contributed notably to the art of cinema; his non-professional actors, ellipses, and sparse use of scoring have led his works to be regarded as preeminent examples of minimalist film.
title: Robert Bresson

text: Bresson is among the most highly regarded French filmmakers of all time.
title: Robert Bresson

text: His works" A Man Escaped"( 1956)," Pickpocket"( 1959) and" Au hasard Balthazar"( 1966) were ranked among the 100 greatest films ever made in the 2012" Sight& Sound" critics' poll.
title: Robert Bresson

text: Other films of his, such as" Mouchette"( 1967) and" L' Argent"( 1983), also received many votes.
title: Robert Bresson

text: Jean- Luc Godard once wrote," He is the French cinema, as Dostoevsky is the Russian novel and Mozart is German[" sic"] music."

title: Prince Karl of Leiningen

text: Princess Victoria Melita of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha , later Grand Duchess Victoria Feodorovna of Russia (25 November 1876 – 2 March 1936) was the third child and second daughter of Alfred, Duke of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha, and Grand Duchess Maria Alexandrovna of Russia.
title: Princess Victoria Melita of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha

text: She was a granddaughter of Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom and Emperor Alexander II of Russia.
title: Princess Victoria Melita of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha

text: Born a British princess, Victoria spent her early life in England and lived in Malta for three years, where her father was serving in the Royal Navy.
title: Princess Victoria Melita of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha

text: In 1889 the family moved to Coburg, where Victoria's father became the reigning duke in 1893.
title: Princess Victoria Melita of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha

text: In her teens Victoria fell in love with her maternal first cousin Grand Duke Kirill Vladimirovich of Russia, but the disapprobation of marriage between first cousins of his faith, Orthodox Christianity, discouraged their romance.
title: Princess Victoria Melita of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha

text: Bowing to family pressure, Victoria married her paternal first cousin, Ernest Louis, Grand Duke of Hesse and by Rhine in 1894, following the wishes of their grandmother, Queen Victoria.
title: Princess Victoria Melita of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha

text: Their marriage was a failure.
title: Princess Victoria Melita of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha

text: Victoria scandalized the royal families of Europe when she divorced her husband in 1901.
title: Princess Victoria Melita of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha

text: The couple's only child, Princess Elisabeth of Hesse and by Rhine, died of typhoid fever in 1903.
title: Princess Victoria Melita of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha

text: Victoria married Grand Duke Kirill Vladimirovich in 1905.
title: Princess Victoria Melita of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha

text: They wed without the formal approval of Britain's King Edward VII, required by the Royal Marriages Act 1772, and in defiance of Tsar Nicholas II.
title: Princess Victoria Melita of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha

text: In retaliation, the Tsar stripped Kirill of his offices and honours, also initially banishing the couple from Russia.
title: Princess Victoria Melita of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha

text: They had two daughters and settled in Paris before being allowed to visit Russia in 1909.
title: Princess Victoria Melita of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha

text: In 1910 they moved to Russia, where Nicholas recognized her as Grand Duchess Victoria Feodorovna.
title: Princess Victoria Melita of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha

text: After the fall of the Russian monarchy in 1917, they escaped to Finland (then part of the Russian Empire) where she gave birth to her only son.
title: Princess Victoria Melita of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha

text: In exile they lived for some years among her relatives in Germany, and from the late 1920s on an estate they bought in Saint-Briac.
title: Princess Victoria Melita of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha

text: In 1926, Kirill proclaimed himself emperor in exile and Victoria supported her husband's claims.
title: Princess Victoria Melita of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha

text: Victoria died after suffering a stroke while visiting her daughter Maria in Amorbach.
title: Princess Victoria Melita of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha

text: Grand Duke Andrei Vladimirovich of Russia ((14 May 1879 – 30 October 1956) was a son of Grand Duke Vladimir Alexandrovich of Russia, a grandson of Emperor Alexander II and a first cousin of Nicholas II, Russia’s last Tsar.
title: Grand Duke Andrei Vladimirovich of Russia

text: In 1900, he began an affair with the famous ballerina Mathilde Kschessinska, becoming the third grand duke to fall for her.
title: Grand Duke Andrei Vladimirovich of Russia

text: Grand Duke Andrei followed a military career and graduated from the Alexandrovskaya Military Law academy in 1905.
title: Grand Duke Andrei Vladimirovich of Russia

text: He occupied different military positions during the reign of Tsar Nicholas II, but with no particular distinction.
title: Grand Duke Andrei Vladimirovich of Russia

text: He became senator in 1911 and was appointed Major General in the Russian Army in 1915.
title: Grand Duke Andrei Vladimirovich of Russia

text: He took part in World War I, but was away from real combat spending most of the conflict at Russia's headquarters or in idle time in Saint Petersburg.
title: Grand Duke Andrei Vladimirovich of Russia

text: In February 1917, shortly before the fall of the Russian monarchy, Grand Duke Andrei left Saint Petersburg to join his mother in Kislovodsk.
title: Grand Duke Andrei Vladimirovich of Russia

text: He remained in the Caucasus for the next three years.
title: Grand Duke Andrei Vladimirovich of Russia

text: After the October Revolution he was briefly arrested along with his brother, Grand Duke Boris, but they escaped.
title: Grand Duke Andrei Vladimirovich of Russia

text: He departed revolutionary Russia in March 1920, being the last grand duke to leave for exile.
title: Grand Duke Andrei Vladimirovich of Russia

text: In 1921, he married his longtime mistress Mathilde Kschessinska and recognized her son as his.
title: Grand Duke Andrei Vladimirovich of Russia

text: The couple lived in the South of France until 1929 when they moved permanently to Paris, where Kschessinska opened a ballet school.
title: Grand Duke Andrei Vladimirovich of Russia

text: After World War II, Grand Duke Andrei lived under reduced circumstances.
title: Grand Duke Andrei Vladimirovich of Russia

text: Until his death at age 77, he was the last surviving Russian grand duke born in Imperial Russia.
title: Grand Duke Andrei Vladimirovich of Russia

text: Grand Duke Kirill Vladimirovich of Russia, ("Kirill Vladimirovich Romanov"; – 12 October 1938) was a son of Grand Duke Vladimir Alexandrovich of Russia, a grandson of Emperor Alexander II and a first cousin of Nicholas II, Russia’s last Tsar.
title: Grand Duke Kirill Vladimirovich of Russia

text: Grand Duke Kirill followed a career in the Russian navy serving during twenty years in the Naval Guards.
title: Grand Duke Kirill Vladimirovich of Russia

text: He took part in the Russo-Japanese War, barely surviving the sinking of the battleship at Port Arthur in April 1904.
title: Grand Duke Kirill Vladimirovich of Russia

text: In 1905, he married his paternal first cousin, Princess Victoria Melita of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha.
title: Grand Duke Kirill Vladimirovich of Russia

text: They wed in defiance of Tsar Nicholas II prohibition.
title: Grand Duke Kirill Vladimirovich of Russia

text: In retaliation, the Tsar stripped Kirill of his offices and honors, also initially banishing the couple from Russia.
title: Grand Duke Kirill Vladimirovich of Russia

text: They had two daughters and settled in Paris before being allowed to visit Russia in 1909.
title: Grand Duke Kirill Vladimirovich of Russia

text: In 1910 they moved to Russia, where Nicholas II recognized their marriage.
title: Grand Duke Kirill Vladimirovich of Russia

text: During World War I, Grand Duke Kirill was appointed Commander of the Naval Depot of the Guards in 1915 and in 1916, he achieved the rank of rear Admiral in the Imperial Navy.
title: Grand Duke Kirill Vladimirovich of Russia

text: During the February Revolution of 1917, Kirill marched to the Tauride Palace at the head of the Naval Guards swearing allegiance to the Russian Provisional Government.
title: Grand Duke Kirill Vladimirovich of Russia

text: During the rule of the provisional governmental in the summer 1917, Kirill escaped to Finland where his wife gave birth to the couple's only son.
title: Grand Duke Kirill Vladimirovich of Russia

text: In exile they lived for some years among his wife's relatives in Germany, and from the late 1920s on an estate they bought in Saint-Briac.
title: Grand Duke Kirill Vladimirovich of Russia

text: With the murder of his cousins Tsar Nicholas II and Grand Duke Michael, Kirill assumed the headship of the Imperial Family of Russia and, as next in line to the throne as the Guardian of the Throne in 1924.
title: Grand Duke Kirill Vladimirovich of Russia

text: Kirill proclaimed himself emperor in exile in 1926.
title: Grand Duke Kirill Vladimirovich of Russia

text: He worked for the restoration of the monarchy from exile for the rest of his life, but his claims were contested by some factions of the monarchy movement in a division that continues until today.
title: Grand Duke Kirill Vladimirovich of Russia

text: He wrote a book of memoirs, "My Life in Russia's Service", published after his death.
title: Grand Duke Kirill Vladimirovich of Russia

text: His granddaughter, Grand Duchess Maria Vladimirovna, is the current claimant to the headship of the House of Romanov.
title: Grand Duke Kirill Vladimirovich of Russia

text: Princess Irene of Hesse and by Rhine(" Irene Luise Marie Anne, Princess of Hesse and by Rhine", 11 July 1866 – 11 November 1953) was the third child and third daughter of Princess Alice of the United Kingdom and Louis IV, Grand Duke of Hesse and by Rhine.
title: Princess Irene of Hesse and by Rhine

text: Her maternal grandparents were Queen Victoria and Prince Albert of Saxe- Coburg and Gotha.
title: Princess Irene of Hesse and by Rhine

text: Her paternal grandparents were Prince Charles of Hesse and by Rhine and Princess Elizabeth of Prussia.
title: Princess Irene of Hesse and by Rhine

text: She was the wife of Prince Henry of Prussia, a younger brother of Wilhelm II, German Emperor and her first cousin.
title: Princess Irene of Hesse and by Rhine

text: The SS" Prinzessin Irene", a liner of the North German Lloyd was named after her.
title: Princess Irene of Hesse and by Rhine

text: Her siblings included Princess Victoria of Hesse and by Rhine, wife of Prince Louis of Battenberg, Grand Duchess Elizabeth Feodorovna of Russia, wife of Grand Duke Sergei Alexandrovich of Russia, Ernest Louis, Grand Duke of Hesse and by Rhine, and Empress Alexandra Feodorovna of Russia, wife of Tsar Nicholas II of Russia.
title: Princess Irene of Hesse and by Rhine

text: Like her younger sister, the empress, Irene was a carrier of the hemophilia gene, and Irene would lose her sisters Alix and Elisabeth in Russia to the Bolsheviks.
title: Princess Irene of Hesse and by Rhine

text: Beat Girl is a 1960 British teen exploitation film directed by Edmond T. Gréville.
title: Beat Girl

text: The film was released in the United States under the title Wild for Kicks.
title: Beat Girl

text: The title character of "Beat Girl" was played by starlet Gillian Hills, who later went on to have numerous small roles in 1960s and 1970s films, such as "Blowup" and "A Clockwork Orange", and became a successful ye-ye singer in France.
title: Beat Girl

text: "Beat Girl" marked the first film roles of British pop idol Adam Faith and actor Peter McEnery, although it was not released until after other films featuring Faith ("Never Let Go") and McEnery ("Tunes of Glory") had already come out.
title: Beat Girl

text: The film also features Christopher Lee and Nigel Green as strip joint operators, and Oliver Reed in a small role as one of the "beat" youth.
title: Beat Girl

text: The original music was composer John Barry's first film commission, and was performed by the John Barry Seven and Orchestra, Adam Faith, and Shirley Anne Field.
title: Beat Girl

text: The "Beat Girl" soundtrack was the first British soundtrack album to be released on a vinyl LP, and it reached number 11 on the UK Albums Chart, paving the way for the release of other film soundtrack albums.
title: Beat Girl

text: Fleetwood Sheppard (sometimes spelled as "Shepphard,Sheppheard," and "Sheppeard") (1 January 1634 – 25 August 1698) was a British courtier and literary wit who was instrumental in the courts of Charles II of England and William of Orange.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: He was an educated man known for his lively wit and honesty, and he was an important figure in the poetry of the 1680s and 1690s.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: He was born in Oxfordshire, attended Magdalen Hall and Christ Church, Oxford, gaining the Bachelor of Arts in 1654 and Master of Arts in 1657.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: When all persons attaining an M.A. were required to join the Church of England, King Charles intervened and said that Sheppard had a background in civil law (having studied at Gray's Inn) and was "not prepared to take orders, he being a person of much ability" (Ellis 255).
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: Instead, Sheppard became a courtier.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: He was introduced to Nell Gwynn and became one of her favourite companions, along with Charles Sackville, Lord Buckhurst (later Earl of Dorset).
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: He would remain one of Dorset's closest friends throughout his life.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: While satirists and gossips (such as Anthony á Wood) said that Sheppard spent his time as "a debauchee and atheist, a grand companion," others suggested that he was a fundamentally honest man who was always interested in a good joke.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: He became one of Charles II's dining companions, and when Nell Gwynn gave birth to a male child, he was made the steward of Gwynn's household.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: This prompted a satirist to accuse him of being the best paid pimp in the land.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: There is little truth to this charge, however, as Sheppard was not paid by the crown for his services, except for two grants of £200.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: Dorset and Sheppard went to Paris together.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: Additionally, Dorset would travel out to meet Sheppard when the latter went out to the country.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: Whether he and Dorset got in trouble in Paris for some scandalous behaviour, as Wood suggests, or not, it is true that Sheppard lived a very active life.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: He was stabbed beneath the eye while separating Henry Bulkeley and George Etheridge in a quarrel in a tavern.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: Sheppard was not liked by James II, and Sheppard did not like James, either.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: When Charles II died, Sheppard went into retirement.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: However, when William came to the throne, Sheppard was back at court and back in favour.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: Dorset was made the chamberlain of the royal household, and that gave him a great many places to dispense in patronage.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: For this, he employed Sheppard.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: Sheppard received the proceeds from those wishing to purchase places, and he received the favours of those wishing a good word to be placed on their behalf.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: At the same time, Sheppard was a favourite of the new Queen's, and John Oldmixon said that he made the Queen "very merry."
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: In "A New Way of Selling Places at Court" in 1712, Jonathan Swift would say that Fleetwood Sheppard sold places that did not exist and named successors for posts that were not vacant, that he enriched himself greatly.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: In 1690 he was made a gentleman usher to the king.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: In 1694 he was knighted, became a gentleman usher to the black rod in the House of Lords, and was inducted as a knight of the garter.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: Sheppard was a patron of many poets and one of those who discovered others.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: He was one of the ones, for example, who "discoveredParadise Lost" when Buckhurst bought it from a small stall at a fair.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: He was also present when Matthew Prior was discovered reading Horace as a tap puller in a bar and sent to school to cultivate his talents.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: He was also one of the main supports of Robert Gould, as well as John Oldmixon.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: He may have embraced the Puritan cause around 1695, and some of his old friends were disaffected by this change.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: Charles Gildon, Thomas Rymer, and John Dennis dedicated volumes of literary criticism to Sheppard, and John Wilmot, 2nd Earl of Rochester regarded Sheppard as the only critic he needed for his verses.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: In his last years, Sheppard was reported dead several times before he died.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: In 1694, Lord Godolphin heard a report that Sheppard had died, but Sheppard himself responded, saying that he was alive, but that he had suffered from "the stone" for twelve to fourteen years.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: In December 1697, he was again reported as dead.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: In July 1698, he was "again" reported as dead.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: He did die shortly afterward, but in 1768 a joking "Annual Register" announced that Sheppard was still alive, in good health, and 120 years old.
title: Fleetwood Sheppard

text: Charles Redheffer was an American inventor who claimed to have invented a perpetual motion machine.
title: Charles Redheffer

text: First appearing in Philadelphia, Redheffer exhibited his machine to the public, charging high prices for viewing.
title: Charles Redheffer

text: When he applied to the government for more money, a group of inspectors were sent to examine the machine.
title: Charles Redheffer

text: It was discovered the machine was actually powered by a device Redheffer claimed was powered by the machine.
title: Charles Redheffer

text: Redheffer moved to New York City and set up a similar scam after rebuilding his machine.
title: Charles Redheffer

text: However, an engineer detected that it was a fake by listening to its unsteady motions at an exhibition.
title: Charles Redheffer

text: He discovered that the machine was operated by a man using a crank in a room on the floor above.
title: Charles Redheffer

text: Redheffer returned to Philadelphia.
title: Charles Redheffer

text: He later claimed to have created another machine, but refused to demonstrate it to anyone.
title: Charles Redheffer

text: He managed to get a patent for his machine in 1820, but after this his fate is unknown.
title: Charles Redheffer

text: Stefan Nemanja (Serbian Cyrillic: Стефан Немања, ; 1113 – 13 February 1199) was the Grand Prince (Veliki Župan) of the Serbian Grand Principality (also known as Raška, lat. "
title: Stefan Nemanja

text: Rascia") from 1166 to 1196.
title: Stefan Nemanja

text: A member of the Vukanović dynasty, Nemanja founded the Nemanjić dynasty, and is remembered for his contributions to Serbian culture and history, founding what would evolve into the Serbian Empire, as well as the national church.
title: Stefan Nemanja

text: According to the Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts, Nemanja is also among the most remarkable Serbs for his literary contributions and altruistic attributes.
title: Stefan Nemanja

text: In 1196, after three decades of warfare and negotiations which consolidated Serbia while distinguishing it from both Western and Byzantine spheres of influence, Nemanja abdicated in favor of his middle son Stefan Nemanjić, who became the first King of Serbia.
title: Stefan Nemanja

text: Nemanja ultimately went to Mount Athos, where he became a monk and took the name of Symeon, joining his youngest son (later known as Saint Sava), who had already become the first archbishop of the Serbian Orthodox Church.
title: Stefan Nemanja

text: Together with his son Sava, Nemanja restored the Hilandar Monastery at Mount Athos from 1198–1199, and issued the "Charter of Hilandar".
title: Stefan Nemanja

text: The monastery later became the cradle of the Serbian Orthodox Church.
title: Stefan Nemanja

text: The Serbian Orthodox Church canonized Stefan Nemanja shortly after his death under the name Saint Simeon
title: Stefan Nemanja

text: the Myrrh-streaming (Свети Симеон Мироточиви) after numerous miracles.
title: Stefan Nemanja

text: Gwenc'hlan is the cognomen of a legendary 6th century Breton druid and bard called Kian, the subject and purported author of a Breton song called" Diougan Gwenc'hlan"( Gwenc'hlan's prophecy), published by Hersart de la Villemarqué in his 1839 anthology" Barzaz Breiz".
title: Gwenc'hlan

text: In this song, Gwenc'hlan is imprisoned after having his eyes gouged out for refusing to convert to Christianity, sings out that he is n't afraid to die and makes a prophecy wherein he will be avenged.
title: Gwenc'hlan

text: The motive of the blinded prisoner is reminiscent of the historical fate of Boethius.
title: Gwenc'hlan

text: One Gwenc'hlan or Guinclaff around 1450 wrote a" chant royal", or" Dialogue between King Arthur and Gwenc'hlan", quoted by Dom Le Pelletier and Gregory of Rostrenen.
title: Gwenc'hlan

text: The poem was rediscovered in 1924.
title: Gwenc'hlan

text: The Breton used by this Gwenc'hlan is already deeply pervaded by French.
title: Gwenc'hlan

text: The legend of the 6th century bard is largely a creation of de la Villemarqué's, but he may have based his account on the 15th century author, as well as on other traditional Breton tales.
title: Gwenc'hlan

text: He quotes 6th to 12th century Welsh poems attributed to the bards Aneurin, Taliesin and Llywarch Hen as his sources.
title: Gwenc'hlan

text: Per Vari Kerloc'h( born 1952) is the current Grand Druid of the" Goursez Breizh"( founded in 1899).
title: Per Vari Kerloc'h

text: He was born at Douarnenez, in the western part of Brittany.
title: Per Vari Kerloc'h

text: The Grand Druid is appointed for life( Kerloc'h succeeded his predecessor Gwenc'hlan Le Scouëzec), whereas the Welsh and Cornish equivalents are now elected every three years.
title: Per Vari Kerloc'h

text: Kerloc'h has been a middle manager and trade union representative with La Poste.
title: Per Vari Kerloc'h

text: He is a native Breton speaker and a fluent speaker of Cornish.
title: Per Vari Kerloc'h

text: His bardic name is" Morgan".
title: Per Vari Kerloc'h

text: Per Vari Kerloc'h was welcomed at the Welsh National Eisteddfod in Cardiff(" Kerdiz" in Breton) in 2008.
title: Per Vari Kerloc'h

text: An article in English published in the newspaper" Connexion" explains that after 2 years as a disciple, it is possible to become an Ovate, Bard or Druid, as in Wales.
title: Per Vari Kerloc'h

text: This is different from Gorseth Kernow which has one order, Bards, and a Grand Bard who is elected for just one 3- year period.
title: Per Vari Kerloc'h

text: " Goursez Breizh" has members who are Christian, Jewish or atheist; on the principle that anyone living in Brittany is Breton.
title: Per Vari Kerloc'h

text: However there are hopes that a younger new leader, rooted in Breton language culture will refocus the" Goursez" on Breton cultural matters as was the original intent of the movement.
title: Per Vari Kerloc'h

text: T. V. Chandran( born 23 November 1950) is an Indian film director, screenwriter, and actor, predominantly working in Malayalam cinema.
title: T. V. Chandran

text: Born in a Malayali family in Telicherry, Chandran worked as a Reserve Bank of India employee before entering into the film industry.
title: T. V. Chandran

text: He started his film career as an assistant director to P. A. Backer.
title: T. V. Chandran

text: He also acted the lead role in Backer's highly acclaimed political drama" Kabani Nadi Chuvannappol"( 1975).
title: T. V. Chandran

text: He made his directorial debut with the unreleased feature" Krishnan Kutty"( 1981), and followed this with the Tamil film" Hemavin Kadhalargal"( 1985).
title: T. V. Chandran

text: Chandran came into prominence after" Alicinte Anveshanam"( 1989), which was nominated for the Golden Leopard at the Locarno International Film Festival.
title: T. V. Chandran

text: This was followed with" Ponthan Mada"( 1993), his most famous film to- date.
title: T. V. Chandran

text: Chandran is most known for his art- house films which have references to history and undertones of politics and feminism.
title: T. V. Chandran

text: He is also known for his trilogy on 2002 Gujarat riots, consisting of" Kathavasheshan"( 2004)," Vilapangalkappuram"( 2008) and" Bhoomiyude Avakashikal"( 2012).
title: T. V. Chandran

text: Other highly acclaimed films include" Mangamma"( 1997)," Dany"( 2001) and( 2003).
title: T. V. Chandran

text: Chandran is widely regarded as one of the finest directors in Indian cinema and is widely credited with having revolutionised parallel cinema with his complex- structured art- house films.
title: T. V. Chandran

text: Chandran has won several film awards including six National Film Awards and ten Kerala State Film Awards.
title: T. V. Chandran

text: In addition to these, he is a recipient of a number of awards at various International film festivals.
title: T. V. Chandran

text: Bhoomiyude Avakashikal
title: Bhoomiyude Avakashikal

text: ( English:" The Inheritors of the Earth") is a 2012 Malayalam feature film written and directed by T. V. Chandran.
title: Bhoomiyude Avakashikal

text: The film stars Kailash in the lead role along with Sreenivasan and Mythili who play pivotal supporting roles.
title: Bhoomiyude Avakashikal

text: The film was produced by Anand Kumar under the banner of Yes Cinema and it was mainly shot in Nelliyampathi, Ottappalam and Shoranur in Kerala.
title: Bhoomiyude Avakashikal

text: " Bhoomiyude Avakashikal" is the third and last installment of T. V. Chandran's trilogy on 2002 Gujarat riots.
title: Bhoomiyude Avakashikal

text: The first one was," Kathavasheshan"( 2004), it was followed by" Vilapangalkkappuram"( 2008).
title: Bhoomiyude Avakashikal

text: The narratives of all these films begin on the same day, 28 February 2002, that is, on the day after the Godhra train burning in Gujarat.
title: Bhoomiyude Avakashikal

text: " Bhoomiyude Avakashikal" tells the story of Mohanachandran Nair, who is driven away from Ahmadabad following the Gujarat riots and who eventually loses his job and even his identity and ultimately lands up in a secluded house in Kerala, in the company of insects and animals with whom he shares his thoughts, concerns, doubts and frustrations.
title: Bhoomiyude Avakashikal

text: The film was shot digitally to reduce costs as it was required to film several insects and animals in their natural habitat.
title: Bhoomiyude Avakashikal

text: The film premiered at the 43rd International Film Festival of India on 27 November 2012.
title: Bhoomiyude Avakashikal

text: It was also an official selection for the International Film Festival of Kerala.
title: Bhoomiyude Avakashikal

text: A prominent critic, Murry is best remembered for his association with Katherine Mansfield, whom he married in 1918 as her second husband, for his friendship with D. H. Lawrence and T. S. Eliot, and for his friendship (and brief affair) with Frieda Lawrence.

text: Following Mansfield's death, Murry edited her work.

text: Only after a short reign, however, the Kakuyid ruler Muhammad ibn Rustam Dushmanziyar overran Hamadan and ended Sama' al- Dawla's rule.

title: Eskandar II

text: He was the son and successor of Taj al- Dawla Ziyar.
title: Eskandar II

text: Ka'us III, was the fourth ruler of the Paduspanid branch of Kojur.
title: Ka'us III

text: He was the son and successor of Ashraf ibn Taj al- Dawla.
title: Ka'us III

text: Asfar ibn Kurduya( also spelled Kurdawayh, Kardawayh and Kurdawaih), was a Daylamite officer who served the Buyid dynasty.
title: Asfar ibn Kurduya

text: Asfar is first mentioned during the reign of the Buyid ruler Adud al- Dawla, as one of the most prominent officers of the Empire.
title: Asfar ibn Kurduya

text: After the death of Adud al- Dawla in 983, the Buyid Empire was thrown into civil war; the Empire was disputed between his two sons Samsam al- Dawla and Sharaf al- Dawla.
title: Asfar ibn Kurduya

text: Samsam al- Dawla ruled Iraq, while Sharaf al- Dawla ruled Fars and Kerman.
title: Asfar ibn Kurduya

text: In 986, Asfar rebelled against Samsam al- Dawla, and changed his allegiance to Sharaf al- Dawla.
title: Asfar ibn Kurduya

text: However, Asfar quickly changed his mind, and declared allegiance to the latter's other brother Abu Nasr Firuz Kharshadh, who was shortly given the" laqab" of" Baha' al- Dawla."
title: Asfar ibn Kurduya

text: However, Samsam al- Dawla, with the aid of Fuladh ibn Manadhar, suppressed the rebellion, and imprisoned Baha al- Dawla.
title: Asfar ibn Kurduya

text: After this event, Asfar is no longer mentioned.
title: Asfar ibn Kurduya

text: Fannā (Panāh) Khusraw , better known by his laqab of ʿAḍud al-Dawla ("Pillar of the [Abbasid] Dynasty")
title: 'Adud al-Dawla

text: (September 24, 936 – March 26, 983) was an emir of the Buyid dynasty, ruling from 949 to 983, and at his height of power ruling an empire stretching from Makran as far to Yemen and the shores of the Mediterranean Sea.
title: 'Adud al-Dawla

text: He is widely regarded as the greatest monarch of the dynasty, and by the end of his reign was the most powerful ruler in the Middle East.
title: 'Adud al-Dawla

text: The son of Rukn al-Dawla, Fanna Khusraw was given the title of Adud al-Dawla by the Abbasid caliph in 948 when he was made emir of Fars after the death of his childless uncle
title: 'Adud al-Dawla

text: Imad al-Dawla, after which Rukn al-Dawla became the senior emir of the Buyids.
title: 'Adud al-Dawla

text: In 974 Adud al-Dawla was sent by his father to save his cousin Izz al-Dawla from a rebellion.
title: 'Adud al-Dawla

text: After defeating the rebel forces, he claimed the emirate of Iraq for himself, and forced his cousin to abdicate.
title: 'Adud al-Dawla

text: His father, however, became angered by this decision and restored Izz al-Dawla.
title: 'Adud al-Dawla

text: After the death of Adud al-Dawla's father, his cousin rebelled against him, but was defeated.
title: 'Adud al-Dawla

text: Adud al-Dawla became afterwards the sole ruler of the Buyid dynasty and assumed the ancient Iranian title of Shahanshah ("King of Kings").
title: 'Adud al-Dawla

text: When Adud al-Dawla became emir of Iraq, the capital city, Baghdad, was suffering from violence and instability owing to sectarian conflict.
title: 'Adud al-Dawla

text: In order to bring peace and stability to the city, he ordered the banning of public demonstrations and polemics.
title: 'Adud al-Dawla

text: At the same time, he patronized a number of Shia scholars such as al-Mufid, and sponsored the renovation of a number of important Shia shrines.
title: 'Adud al-Dawla

text: In addition, 'Adud al-Dawla is credited with sponsoring and patronizing other scientific projects during his time.
title: 'Adud al-Dawla

text: An observatory was built by his orders in Isfahan where Azophi worked.
title: 'Adud al-Dawla

text: Al-Muqaddasi also reports that he ordered the construction of a great dam between Shiraz and Estakhr in 960.
title: 'Adud al-Dawla

text: The dam irrigated some 300 villages in Fars province and became known as "Band-e Amir" (Dam of the emir).
title: 'Adud al-Dawla

text: Among his other major constructions was the digging of the Haffar channel, that joined the Karun river to the Shatt al-Arab river (the confluence of the Tigris and the Euphrates).
title: 'Adud al-Dawla

text: The port of Khorramshahr was built on the Haffar, at its joining point with the Shatt al-Arab.
title: 'Adud al-Dawla

text: Ali ibn Kama, the uncle of the Buyid ruler Rukn al- Dawla and the latter's other brothers Mu'izz al- Dawla and Imad al- Dawla, was a Buyid military officer who became prominent among the Buyids of Jibal, and was greatly honored among his Daylamite kinsmen.
title: Ali ibn Kama

text: At the death of Imad al- Dawla in 949, Ali was appointed as the viceroy of Ray by Rukn al- Dawla, who went to Shiraz to secure the succession of his son there, Adud al- Dawla.
title: Ali ibn Kama

text: Meanwhile, the Samanids used this opportunity to invade the territories of Rukn al- Dawla, forcing Ali to flee from Jibal.
title: Ali ibn Kama

text: In ca. 959, a battle ensured between Ali and the Ziyarid prince Bisutun, which resulted in a Buyid victory.
title: Ali ibn Kama

text: In 966, Ali and Rukn al- Dawla defeated a large force of" ghazis" who had arrived from Khorasan.
title: Ali ibn Kama

text: Rukn al- Dawla later died in 976 and was succeeded by his son Fakhr al- Dawla, who had Ali executed.
title: Ali ibn Kama

text: ʿ Azīz al- Dawla Abū Shujāʿ Fātik al- Waḥīd ī ibn ʿ Abd Allāh al- Rūmī, better known simply as Aziz al- Dawla( d. 1022), was the first Fatimid governor of Aleppo in 1016/ 17–1022.
title: Aziz al-Dawla

text: An ethnic Armenian, Aziz al- Dawla started his political career as a trusted" ghulam"( military slave) of Manjutakin al- Azizi, the Fatimid governor of Damascus during the reign of Caliph al- Hakim( 996–1021).
title: Aziz al-Dawla

text: The latter appointed Aziz al- Dawla governor of Aleppo, which experienced prosperity during his rule.
title: Aziz al-Dawla

text: By 1020, Aziz al- Dawla was acting independently of al- Hakim's authority by issuing coins in his name and having his political sovereignty declared in Friday prayers.
title: Aziz al-Dawla

text: When al- Hakim sent an army to force Aziz al- Dawla into submission, the latter appealed for Byzantine support but canceled the appeal when al- Hakim mysteriously disappeared in early 1021.
title: Aziz al-Dawla

text: Afterward, the Fatimid court attempted to reconcile with Aziz al- Dawla, who nonetheless moved to secure his rule by building a well- fortified palace at the foot of the Aleppo's citadel.
title: Aziz al-Dawla

text: In July 1022, Aziz al- Dawla was murdered in his sleep by one of his" ghulams"( slave soldier) in a plot devised by another of his" ghulams", Abu'l- Najm Badr, with likely backing from al- Hakim's virtual successor, Sitt al- Mulk.
title: Aziz al-Dawla

text: Badr briefly succeeded Aziz al- Dawla as governor but was arrested three months later.
title: Aziz al-Dawla

text: Ziyar ibn Shahrakuya( also spelled Shahrakawayh), was a high- ranking Gilaki military officer who served the Buyids.
title: Ziyar ibn Shahrakuya

text: Ziyar was the son of Shahrakawayh, the son of Harusindan, the maternal uncle of the Ziyarid ruler Mardavij.
title: Ziyar ibn Shahrakuya

text: Ziyar had a cousin, who married the Buyid ruler Adud al- Dawla, and bore him one son named Abu Kalijar Marzuban.
title: Ziyar ibn Shahrakuya

text: During that period, Ziyar, along with a Daylamite officer named Fuladh ibn Manadhar, dominated the Buyid court of Baghdad.
title: Ziyar ibn Shahrakuya

text: After the death of Adud al- Dawla in 983, the Buyid Empire was thrown into civil war; the Empire was disputed between his two sons Abu Kalijar Marzuban( who took the name Samsam al- Dawla) and Sharaf al- Dawla.
title: Ziyar ibn Shahrakuya

text: The Turkic soldiers of Iraq shortly betrayed Samsam al- Dawla, and went towards to the court of Sharaf al- Dawla.
title: Ziyar ibn Shahrakuya

text: However, Ziyar managed to make most of them change their mind and stay loyal to Samsam al- Dawla.
title: Ziyar ibn Shahrakuya

text: In 987, Sharaf al- Dawla marched towards Baghdad and deposed Samsam al- Dawla.
title: Ziyar ibn Shahrakuya

text: He then imprisoned Fuladh and had Ziyar executed.
title: Ziyar ibn Shahrakuya

text: Abu'l-Husain Ahmad , better known by his "laqab" of Taj al-Dawla
title: Taj al-Dawla

text: (Arabic: تاج الدولة،, "Crown of the Dynasty"), was the Buyid ruler of Khuzestan during the 980s.
title: Taj al-Dawla

text: He was the son of 'Adud al-Dawla.
title: Taj al-Dawla

text: Ṣafiyy al- Dawla Muḥammad
title: Safiyy al-Dawla

text: ibn ʿ Ali ibn Jaʾfar ibn Falāh was the Fatimid governor of Aleppo between October 1022 and April 1023.
title: Safiyy al-Dawla

text: He was specifically assigned to govern the city, while the citadel of Aleppo was assigned to a separate governor, the eunuch Yumn al- Dawla Sa'adat.
title: Safiyy al-Dawla

text: This marked the first time the Fatimids appointed separate rulers for the city and citadel of Aleppo since they gained direct control over the city in October 1016.
title: Safiyy al-Dawla

text: Safiyy al- Dawla belonged to the Kutama, a militant Berber group that played a major role in the Fatimid military, and he was the grandson of the Fatimid general Ja'far ibn Fallah.
title: Safiyy al-Dawla

text: He was bestowed with the title" ṣafiyy al- dawla"( chosen of the State).
title: Safiyy al-Dawla

text: Safiyy al- Dawla and Yumn al- Dawla were appointed to Aleppo to replace Abu'l- Najm Badr.
title: Safiyy al-Dawla

text: Nothing is known about their reign and Safiyy al- Dawla was dismissed in April 1023, and succeeded by Sanad al- Dawla Hasan.
title: Safiyy al-Dawla

text: Curtis Bernhardt( 15 April 1899 – 22 February 1981) was a German film director born in Worms, Germany, under the name Kurt Bernhardt.
title: Curtis Bernhardt

text: He trained as an actor in Germany, and performed on the stage, before starting as a film director in 1924, with" Nameless Heroes".
title: Curtis Bernhardt

text: Other films include" A Stolen Life"( 1946) and" Sirocco"( 1951).
title: Curtis Bernhardt

text: Bernhardt made films in Germany from 1925 until 1933, when he was forced to flee the Nazi regime — who briefly had him arrested — because he was Jewish.
title: Curtis Bernhardt

text: Bernhardt directed films in France and England before moving on to Hollywood to work for Warner Brothers in 1940.
title: Curtis Bernhardt

text: He produced and directed his last Hollywood picture," Kisses for My President"( 1964), about the nation's first female Chief Executive starring Polly Bergen and Fred MacMurray.
title: Curtis Bernhardt

text: He is interred at Glendale's Forest Lawn Memorial Park Cemetery, near his wife, Pearl Argyle Wellman Bernhardt.
title: Curtis Bernhardt

text: Payment on Demand is a 1951 drama film directed by Curtis Bernhardt and starring Bette Davis and Barry Sullivan.

text: The screenplay by Bernhardt and Bruce Manning chronicles a marriage from its idealistic early days to its dissolution.
title: Payment on Demand

text: Alfred Albert Thomas William Adams( 24 June 1842 – 1 June 1919), known as Thomas William Adams, was a New Zealand farmer, forester, churchman and educationalist.
title: Thomas William Adams

text: He was born in Graveley, Cambridgeshire, England on 24 June 1842.
title: Thomas William Adams

text: In 1862 he emigrated to New Zealand on the" African".
title: Thomas William Adams

text: He bought of virgin tussock land at Greendale in Canterbury in 1865 and converted them to farmland.
title: Thomas William Adams

text: The area prospered over the next few years as more farmers developed land.
title: Thomas William Adams

text: Adams married Lucy Pannett in 1867 and they had a daughter the following year.
title: Thomas William Adams

text: Lucy drowned in 1869.
title: Thomas William Adams

text: Adams married her sister Harriet in 1872, and they had five sons and three daughters together.
title: Thomas William Adams

text: Adams was a pioneer in planting trials, obtaining seeds from correspondents around the world, keeping records and publishing the results.
title: Thomas William Adams

text: He started planting trees in 1868 for shelter and fuel, and by 1908 had created an arboretum of 800 species.
title: Thomas William Adams

text: His recommendation of" Pinus radiata" and other pines influenced early New Zealand forestry.
title: Thomas William Adams

text: In 1913 he was a member of the Royal Commission on Forestry, and in 1918 he became a lifetime member of the New Zealand Forestry League.
title: Thomas William Adams

text: For 40 years, Adams taught Sunday school at Greendale, which began by teaching local children to read.
title: Thomas William Adams

text: He was instrumental in the formation of the Greendale day school in 1872, and served on the North Canterbury Education Board from 1892 to 1918, serving as chairman from 1897 to 1905.
title: Thomas William Adams

text: He was also a governor of Canterbury College( now University of Canterbury) from 1897 until his death.
title: Thomas William Adams

text: He was the first secretary of the Canterbury Baptist Association, and later its president.
title: Thomas William Adams

text: Adams died at Greendale on 1 June 1919 and was buried there.
title: Thomas William Adams

text: His will left £ 2000 and of land to Canterbury College to be used for a school of forestry.
title: Thomas William Adams

text: Harriet died 15 January 1934 and was buried with him.
title: Thomas William Adams

text: The school of forestry opened in 1924, and about 1975 a T.W. Adams Scholarship was set up to support postgraduate forestry students.
title: Thomas William Adams

text: Simonds Catholic College is a Roman Catholic school for boys located in Melbourne.

text: The college is an associate member of the Associated Catholic Colleges History Simonds was formed in 1996 through the amalgamation of Cathedral College, East Melbourne and St Mary's Boys School.

text: In 2010, the former St Brigid's Primary School in North Fitzroy was renovated, and a new senior campus of the college was opened there.

text: The school is named after Justin Simonds, the first ever Australian born Archbishop who served as Archbishop of Melbourne from 1963- 67.

text: He also served as parish priest of St Mary ’s where the Years 7- 10 campus is located.

text: Houses Students at Simonds are placed into houses at the start of commencement of year 7 and remain in the same house until Graduation.

text: The schools houses are Goold, Knox, Manix, Polding.
title: Simonds Catholic College

text: Each house is named after a previous Archbishop of Melbourne

text: Throughout the year students are awarded points for their houses through house sports, co-curriculum activities, academic performance and many more ways.
title: Simonds Catholic College

text: The main house competitions are the Swimming Carnival and the Athletics Carnival.

title: Alexandre Louis Philippe Marie Berthier, 4th Prince of Wagram

text: Through a relationship with Marie- Louise Salivas dite Welson, he had a daughter, Monique Berthier de Wagram( 1914–2000).
title: Alexandre Louis Philippe Marie Berthier, 4th Prince of Wagram

text: Alexandre Berthier had not yet married when he was killed in action at Barenton- sur- Cere during World War I.
title: Alexandre Louis Philippe Marie Berthier, 4th Prince of Wagram

title: Alexandre Louis Philippe Marie Berthier, 4th Prince of Wagram

text: Seth Gordon Persons( February 5, 1902 – May 29, 1965) was an American Democratic politician who was the 43rd Governor of Alabama from 1951 to 1955.
title: Gordon Persons

text: He was born and died in Montgomery, Alabama.
title: Gordon Persons

text: The Dauphin Island Bridge south of Mobile is formally named for him.
title: Gordon Persons

text: The Gordon Persons Building is a six floor, 60,000 square foot state government office building in Montgomery.
title: Gordon Persons

text: Persons built a successful business running electrical lines in rural Alabama( benefiting from Rural Electrification Administration contracts); in addition to financial gain, he also won considerable popularity.
title: Gordon Persons

text: When running for office in 1950, Persons gained notoriety by touring the state in a helicopter( prompting one opponent to dub him" the man from Mars").
title: Gordon Persons

text: He won the Democratic nomination by defeating a crowded field that included former governor Chauncey Sparks.
title: Gordon Persons

text: In office, his notable accomplishments included abolishing flogging in Alabama's prisons, advocating for the establishment of Alabama Public Television, and imposing speed limits on state highways.
title: Gordon Persons

text: Persons largely accomplished his goal of having four years of" no fighting," maintaining a truce among the various wings of the state Democratic Party.
title: Gordon Persons

text: At the end of his term, Persons ordered the National Guard into Phenix City following the assassination of Attorney- General- elect Albert Patterson.
title: Gordon Persons

text: After leaving office as governor, Persons never sought statewide public office again, although he did make an unsuccessful run for circuit judge late in life.
title: Gordon Persons

text: Persons was an alumnus of Auburn University, though he attended for only one year.
title: Gordon Persons

text: While at Auburn, Persons served as president of a student organization( known as the" Boxcar Reds and Boxcar Blacks") that traveled to away football games.
title: Gordon Persons

text: Lucio Fulci( 17 June 1927 – 13 March 1996) was an Italian film director, screenwriter, producer, and actor.
title: Lucio Fulci

text: Although he worked in a wide array of genres through a career spanning nearly five decades, including comedy, spaghetti western, adventure, science fiction and erotica, he garnered an international cult following for his giallo and horror films.

text: His most notable films include the" Gates of Hell" trilogy —" City of the Living Dead"( 1980)," The Beyond"( 1981), and" The House by the Cemetery"( 1981) —as well as" Massacre Time"( 1966)," One on Top of the Other"( 1969)," A Lizard in a Woman's Skin"( 1971)," Do n't Torture a Duckling"( 1972)," White Fang"( 1973)," Four of the Apocalypse"( 1975)," Sette note in nero"( 1977)," Zombi 2"( 1979)," Contraband"( 1980)," The Black Cat"( 1981)," The New York Ripper"( 1982)," Murder Rock"( 1984), and" A Cat in the Brain"( 1990).
title: Lucio Fulci

text: Because of the high level of visceral graphic violence present in many of his films, especially" Zombi 2" and" The Beyond", Fulci is frequently referred to as" The Godfather of Gore", a title also given to Herschell Gordon Lewis.
title: Lucio Fulci

text: Fulci was in his young adult years a politically active radical for the Italian Communist Party.
title: Lucio Fulci

text: According to Hasidic legend, Adam Baal Shem of Ropczyce was a rabbi and mystic who first introduced the movement of Hasidism.
title: Adam Baal Shem

text: The leadership of the movement was later handed down from Rabbi Adam to Rabbi Yisrael ben Eliezer, the Baal Shem Tov.
title: Adam Baal Shem

text: The exact identity of Rabbi Adam is unknown.
title: Adam Baal Shem

text: Since the name Adam was rare among European Jewry, Gershom Scholem considers it to be a pseudonym for Heshel Zoref( died 1700).
title: Adam Baal Shem

text: According to Aryeh Kaplan, others identify this Adam with Rabbi David Moshe Abraham( whose initials are Adam) of Troyes or with Adam Zerweiker.
title: Adam Baal Shem

text: Kaplan also writes that it may be an anonym to protect the subject's identity.
title: Adam Baal Shem

text: According to Rabbi Yosef Yitzchak Schneersohn, Rabbi Adam was a disciple of Rabbi Yoel Baal Shem of Zamość, who in turn was a disciple of Rabbi Eliyahu Baal Shem of Worms.
title: Adam Baal Shem

text: According to the" Shivhei HaBesht", Rabbi Adam found manuscripts in a cave, containing hidden secrets of the Torah.
title: Adam Baal Shem

text: Rabbi Adam asked in a dream to whom should he hand down the manuscripts?
title: Adam Baal Shem

text: During the fifth match, his economy was just over 3 runs per over – a very good figure for any bowler, especially a spinner.

text: A tall man at 6'4", Arshad bowls in a classical off-spinner's mould, preferring a nagging line to any great variation.
